alternatives.transcript: Welcome to another GIMP tutorial. In this video, we'll be learning about the move and also the crop tool. So crop is a fancy word for cut. It's the way that we would cut out a certain area like this and then it selects that we hit enter and now we've cut kind of the outside of our image away and then move as you know is just going to move our image or we can move parts of the image as well. So we'll learn how to do that. I'm doing control z to get this back to where it was originally. So let's slow down and go over these one at a time. Let's do the crop first. There's a couple ways to do crop. When we select the crop tool, it's shift c is the shortcut and the icon looks like this and again these icons may be in a different location for you if you're depending on how your dialog is sized and also what version of GIMP you're using the icons may even look different but find your crop tool and then to use it we just left click and hold the mouse down the left mouse button and when we unclick it shades out the area that will be cut out and it keeps highlighted the area that is, going to be remaining. And then we hit the enter key on our keyboard and it performs that cut. If we don't like it we can go control z and just go back and we can redraw or a better way is to just use these handles here before we hit enter. We can use these handles to sort of fine tune and really crop into the area that we want. We can also click on the corners and resize. This is sort of similar to the way we drew selections where when we resize one corner is fixed and a shortcut we didn't really go over is if we hold down the control key while we're in the selection resize mode we can resize from based off of the center. So I'm holding down the control key right now rather than having a fixed point. Also what you might try is holding down the shift key and that'll let us scale uniformly. So even if I come down here and try and go just over to the right any distance I go horizontally will also go vertically when the shift key is held while in this resize mode. Does that make sense? I'm gonna hit enter to confirm this crop. The move tool we've used in the past. When the move tool is selected, it'll move either the layer. We can also tell it to move the selection or the path based on these different modes over here. But make sure you're on this move by layer and then right now it's just picking the active layer. So whatever layer I click on will move. I only have one layer right now. But to illustrate this a little bit better, let's bring in a new image and keep this one here. So I'll go file open and I'll select this image right here. So now I have two different projects. I can see up top here. There's this one of me standing in the snow. This is actually my brother here. And so I can copy this image of my brother by going to right click and edit and go to copy. Or I can press control c on the keyboard and that's now copied to the clipboard, this image. Then I can go over to the other image and go control v on my keyboard to paste it. Or I can right click and go to edit and go to paste. And that will paste this image. Well now I can click on the move tool and I can move this image around. It's actually a layer if you notice over here. It's a floating selection. It's a separate layer from this image. So it's kinda like there's two layers right now. We can do two things. We can choose to merge this as part of this image and combine them into one layer to do that we just right click over here and go to anchor layer now it's anchored in there and if we try to move it it'll everything will move together any scaling or anything we apply is going to move all these together I can go control z and get back to that point before I did the merge because we can also right click and go to new layer and what that does it puts this floating selection on its own new layer. Now we have two layers. We can click and see each one individually and this lets us be able to still move this around. We can crop just this image or just either one of these images independently from the other. If we do the crop tool right now and we wanna crop in just a part of this image but keep everything out here unaffected, we don't do it this way. If we do, it'll just crop in like this. But I can go control z and before I select the crop notice there's some options under crop as well. There's one called current layer only if I check that and then draw my crop selection and then hit enter, it will only crop just the layer that I'm working on. Does that make sense? And so, if we didn't have that selected, then it would treat everything as one and crop all layers together. There's also some other options here and we'll play with more of these in the future. We can so we can instead of drawing this, we could draw and then we could fine tune it over here and change the size. You notice as I click these, it's moving subtly the size of it and we can also use our scroll wheel to change that as well. There is one more way to crop I wanna show you and that is just by using the selection tool. So we can select an area and it looks similar to crop only notice when the selection tool is used it doesn't everything else get grayed out and if we hit enter, it doesn't crop or do anything. So the selection tool, even though the interface sort of looks the same and we can resize it, it's not the crop tool. So pay attention to that. But what this will let us do is, when we have a selection, we can crop to that selection. All we have to do is click on, image and go to crop to selection and that will crop to whatever we have selected. We talked about that a little bit in the past like if we were to do a circle selection and we wanna crop to a circle, it'll still do it as a square. We can go image crop to, selection and that'll kind of crop that out. So there's some ways we'll learn, how we could cut out if we wanted to have transparency in the corners there. But just know you can, crop that way as well by cropping to whatever you have selected but it'll still always crop in a square or rectangle. Well hopefully you found this informative. Go ahead and play with crop and play with move and next videos we're going to be doing some more of this where we copy, certain images and paste them. We'll be playing with rotate and sheer and learning how to composite multiple images together appreciate you watching leave your questions comments below and I'll catch you in the next video

And then we hit the enter key on our keyboard and it performs that cut. If we don't like it we can go control z and just go back and we can redraw or a better way is to just use these handles here before we hit enter. We can use these handles to sort of fine tune and really crop into the area that we want. We can also click on the corners and resize. I'm gonna hit enter to confirm this crop.

The move tool we've used in the past. When the move tool is selected, it'll move either the layer. We can also tell it to move the selection or the path based on these different modes over here. But make sure you're on this move by layer and then right now it's just picking the active layer. So whatever layer I click on will move.

I only have one layer right now. But to illustrate this a little bit better, let's bring in a new image and keep this one here. So I'll go file open and I'll select this image right here. So now I have two different projects. I can see up top here.

There's this one of me standing in the snow. This is actually my brother here. And so I can copy this image of my brother by going to right click and edit and go to copy. Or I can press control c on the keyboard and that's now copied to the clipboard, this image. Then I can go over to the other image and go control v on my keyboard to paste it.

It's a separate layer from this image. So it's kinda like there's two layers right now. We can do two things. Now we have two layers.

We can click and see each one individually and this lets us be able to still move this around. We can crop just this image or just either one of these images independently from the other. If we do the crop tool right now and we wanna crop in just a part of this image but keep everything out here unaffected, we don't do it this way. If we do, it'll just crop in like this. But I can go control z and before I select the crop notice there's some options under crop as well.

There's one called current layer only if I check that and then draw my crop selection and then hit enter, it will only crop just the layer that I'm working on. Does that make sense? And so, if we didn't have that selected, then it would treat everything as one and crop all layers together. There's also some other options here and we'll play with more of these in the future. We can so we can instead of drawing this, we could draw and then we could fine tune it over here and change the size.

You notice as I click these, it's moving subtly the size of it and we can also use our scroll wheel to change that as well. There is one more way to crop I wanna show you and that is just by using the selection tool. So we can select an area and it looks similar to crop only notice when the selection tool is used it doesn't everything else get grayed out and if we hit enter, it doesn't crop or do anything. So the selection tool, even though the interface sort of looks the same and we can resize it, it's not the crop tool. So pay attention to that.

But what this will let us do is, when we have a selection, we can crop to that selection. All we have to do is click on, image and go to crop to selection and that will crop to whatever we have selected. We talked about that a little bit in the past like if we were to do a circle selection and we wanna crop to a circle, it'll still do it as a square. We can go image crop to, selection and that'll kind of crop that out. So there's some ways we'll learn, how we could cut out if we wanted to have transparency in the corners there.

But just know you can, crop that way as well by cropping to whatever you have selected but it'll still always crop in a square or rectangle. Well hopefully you found this informative. Go ahead and play with crop and play with move and next videos we're going to be doing some more of this where we copy, certain images and paste them. sentences.text: Welcome to another GIMP tutorial.
In this video, we'll be learning about the move and also the crop tool.
So crop is a fancy word for cut.

It's the way that we would cut out a certain area like this and then it selects that we hit enter and now we've cut kind of the outside of our image away and then move as you know is just going to move our image or we can move parts of the image as well.
So we'll learn how to do that.
I'm doing control z to get this back to where it was originally.
So let's slow down and go over these one at a time.
Let's do the crop first.
There's a couple ways to do crop.

When we select the crop tool, it's shift c is the shortcut and the icon looks like this and again these icons may be in a different location for you if you're depending on how your dialog is sized and also what version of GIMP you're using the icons may even look different but find your crop tool and then to use it we just left click and hold the mouse down the left mouse button and when we unclick it shades out the area that will be cut out and it keeps highlighted the area that is, going to be remaining.
And then we hit the enter key on our keyboard and it performs that cut.
If we don't like it we can go control z and just go back and we can redraw or a better way is to just use these handles here before we hit enter.
We can use these handles to sort of fine tune and really crop into the area that we want.
We can also click on the corners and resize.

This is sort of similar to the way we drew selections where when we resize one corner is fixed and a shortcut we didn't really go over is if we hold down the control key while we're in the selection resize mode we can resize from based off of the center.
So I'm holding down the control key right now rather than having a fixed point.
Also what you might try is holding down the shift key and that'll let us scale uniformly.
So even if I come down here and try and go just over to the right any distance I go horizontally will also go vertically when the shift key is held while in this resize mode.
Does that make sense?
I'm gonna hit enter to confirm this crop.
The move tool we've used in the past.
When the move tool is selected, it'll move either the layer.
We can also tell it to move the selection or the path based on these different modes over here.
But make sure you're on this move by layer and then right now it's just picking the active layer.
So whatever layer I click on will move.
I only have one layer right now.
But to illustrate this a little bit better, let's bring in a new image and keep this one here.
So I'll go file open and I'll select this image right here.
So now I have two different projects.
I can see up top here.
There's this one of me standing in the snow.
This is actually my brother here.
And so I can copy this image of my brother by going to right click and edit and go to copy.
Or I can press control c on the keyboard and that's now copied to the clipboard, this image.
Then I can go over to the other image and go control v on my keyboard to paste it.
Or I can right click and go to edit and go to paste.
And that will paste this image.
Well now I can click on the move tool and I can move this image around.
It's actually a layer if you notice over here.
It's a floating selection.
It's a separate layer from this image.
So it's kinda like there's two layers right now.
We can do two things.

We can choose to merge this as part of this image and combine them into one layer to do that we just right click over here and go to anchor layer now it's anchored in there and if we try to move it it'll everything will move together any scaling or anything we apply is going to move all these together I can go control z and get back to that point before I did the merge because we can also right click and go to new layer and what that does it puts this floating selection on its own new layer.
Now we have two layers.
We can click and see each one individually and this lets us be able to still move this around.
We can crop just this image or just either one of these images independently from the other.
If we do the crop tool right now and we wanna crop in just a part of this image but keep everything out here unaffected, we don't do it this way.
If we do, it'll just crop in like this.
But I can go control z and before I select the crop notice there's some options under crop as well.
There's one called current layer only if I check that and then draw my crop selection and then hit enter, it will only crop just the layer that I'm working on.
Does that make sense?
And so, if we didn't have that selected, then it would treat everything as one and crop all layers together.
There's also some other options here and we'll play with more of these in the future.
We can so we can instead of drawing this, we could draw and then we could fine tune it over here and change the size.
You notice as I click these, it's moving subtly the size of it and we can also use our scroll wheel to change that as well.
There is one more way to crop I wanna show you and that is just by using the selection tool.
So we can select an area and it looks similar to crop only notice when the selection tool is used it doesn't everything else get grayed out and if we hit enter, it doesn't crop or do anything.
So the selection tool, even though the interface sort of looks the same and we can resize it, it's not the crop tool.
So pay attention to that.
But what this will let us do is, when we have a selection, we can crop to that selection.
All we have to do is click on, image and go to crop to selection and that will crop to whatever we have selected.
We talked about that a little bit in the past like if we were to do a circle selection and we wanna crop to a circle, it'll still do it as a square.
We can go image crop to, selection and that'll kind of crop that out.

But just know you can, crop that way as well by cropping to whatever you have selected but it'll still always crop in a square or rectangle.
Well hopefully you found this informative.
